metadata.titleEn: A data set about the Cenozoic climate, environment and weathering evolution in the eastern Tibetan Plateau and its adjacent area
metadata.description: The reconstruction of the Cenozoic climate, environment, and weathering evolution process in the Tibetan Plateau and its adjacent area, the extraction and analysis of major climate events have important reference significance for understanding the relationship between "Tibetan Plateau uplift-chemical weathering-global cooling". This data set consists of the reconstructed paleoenvironmental evolution data by using many methods such as granularity, environmental magnetism, mineralogy, element and isotope geochemistry, organic geochemistry, and palynology, based on the Cenozoic sedimentary records from the eastern Tibetan Plateau and its adjacent area (Tarim, Qaidam, Hoh Xil, Nangqian, Jinchuan, Xining, Lanzhou, Binxian and Shilou). The paleoclimatic and paleoenvironmental information (such as palaeoelevation, paleotemperature, paleohumidity, paleovegetation, and climate events) provide important data support for discussing the dynamic mechanisms and links among the chemical weathering and paleoclimate, the uplift of the Tibetan Plateau, global change and the orbital periodic changes.
metadata.instructions: The data files are named based on their contents. They were stored as .xlsx files and can be opened and read by the Excel program directly. Please read the readme file first before using the data.

background: Continuous and accurately dated sediment records from the Asian interior are pivotal to a better understanding of the evolutionary history of Asian inland drying and the associated driving mechanisms. The Asian inland drying is generally regarded as a coupling consequence of land-sea-atmosphere interaction, which could be dated back to the early Eocene and significantly enhanced since the late Oligocene-early Miocene. The driving mechanism appears to correspond closely with the uplift of the Tibetan Plateau, the retreat of the Para-Tethys Sea, and global cooling with Cenozoic development of bipolar glaciations and continental ice sheets. Especially during the Neogene-Quaternary, the regional drying and eolian dust activity have been greatly enhanced in the Asian interior. However, intensive tectonic activity since the late Oligocene-Early Miocene in the northern Tibetan Plateau and the Central Asian orogenic belt yields much coarser lithology with frequent changes in sediment facies in basin sequences, which hinders a better understanding of the full range of aridification and its driving force using the basin sediment records. The Qaidam Basin, an inland arid area in the northeast Tibetan Plateau, is dominantly under the influence of the middle-latitude westerlies, with its southeast corner being impacted by the East Asian monsoons, thus providing the ideal area to reveal tectonic-climate linkages in terms of aridification of the Asian interior.
research objective: In this study, we present a continuous record of climate change in the Asian interior spanning the past 7.3 Myr, reconstructed by the redox evolution of a paleolake in the western Qaidam Basin, NE Tibetan Plateau. We thus integrated new data of carbonate Mn concentration from the SG-1b core (7.3 – 1.6 Ma) with the previous SG-1 Mn records to reconstruct a continuous history of paleolake and climate evolution in the western Qaidam Basin since 7.3 Ma.
methods: We used the 1M HOAc to leach the sediments in order to obtain the Mn(II) concentrations in the lacustrine sediments. A total of 619 bulk samples of the SG-1b core were selected for geochemical analysis. Samples were oven-dried at 40 °C and ground into fine powder (<200 mesh). Approximately 0.5 g of each sample was leached by 10 ml 1M HOAc at room temperature for 24 h to extract Mn in the carbonate fraction of the samples. Concentrations of Mn, Ca, Mg, and Sr in the acetic acid leachate were analyzed by inductively coupled plasma-optical emission spectrometry (ICP-OES) (Leeman Labs Prodigy-H). To obtain the major minerals (especially carbonate minerals in the core), we chose seven representative samples of SG-1b core for X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis using a Rigaku D/MAX-2000 diffractometer (Cu, Kα, 1.5406 Å, 40 kV, 100 mA, 3–35°, step 0.02°,1 0°/min) at the Micro Structure Analytical Laboratory, Peking University.
dataset: The SG-1b drilling campaign was performed at the top of the Jianshan Anticline in the western Qaidam Basin, 100 km northeast of Lenghu Town, and about 20 km east of the SG-1 borehole. The drilling extended 723m in depth with an average recovery rate of 93%. The SG-1b drill-core was dated at about 7.3 – 1.6 Ma with magnetostratigraphy, refined by orbital tuning in the period of 3.3–2.1 Ma.
findings: The XRD results show that major minerals in the sediments of SG-1b core include quartz, albite, orthoclase, carbonate minerals (calcite, aragonite, dolomite, and ankerite), mica or illite, and chlorite (Figure 3). The concentration of Ca in acetic acid leachates (Ca HOAc) mainly represents the calcium carbonate and some Ca-bearing salt minerals (e.g., gypsum) content in the sediments. Consequently, the measured Ca concentrations reflect the calcium carbonate content below 232 m and an upper limit of the calcium carbonate content above 232 m. The MnHOAc variation reveals an upward decrease above ∼240 m and a long-term relative stable content with several fluctuations below ∼240 m (Figure 4). The MnHOAc concentrations present long-term fluctuations of regional climate. The integrated MnHOAc record is especially more synchronous with the North Atlantic Ocean SST (Figure 5), suggesting that the reduction of westerlies moisture caused by high-latitude cooling of the Northern Hemisphere directly affects the aridification of the Qaidam Basin. The recurrence analysis has been successfully used to determine the climate state transitions using high-resolution proxy records, e.g., the Cenozoic climate (Westerhold et al., 2020) and the Quaternary climate in the Qaidam Basin (Han et al., 2020). The result of recurrence analysis of the integrated MnHOAc record shows three major transitions at 6.2 Ma, 5.3 Ma, and 2.6 Ma. The 5.3 Ma change, i.e., at about the Miocene/Pliocene boundary, is a transition stage from the prior drying stage to the subsequent wetting stage in the Qaidam Basin, which is consistent with global warming at that time (Figure 5). The system change at the Pliocene/Quaternary boundary (2.6 Ma) marks the onset of prolonged and extensive Quaternary drying in the Qaidam Basin, which is contemporaneous with the intensification of the North Hemisphere glaciation. Therefore, global change and northern hemisphere high latitude processes could modulate the Asian inland climate at orbital time scales, which is also supported with other studies of high-resolution Quaternary records in the SG-1 core (e.g., Han et al., 2020).

background: The Linxia Basin on the north-eastern Tibetan Plateau in northwest China bears continuous and thick lacustrine-fluvial sediments with environmental significance to central Asian aridification. Climate change since the mid-Oligocene in central Asia has been specifically interesting as it is a critical period in the growth of the Tibetan Plateau. Many researchers believed that the arid conditions in continental Asia had developed as a result of the uplift of the Tibetan Plateau. The Linxia Basin lies topographically at the intersection of the East Asian monsoon region, the arid region of northwest China, and the alpine region of the Tibetan Plateau. Lipid biomarkers have been suggested as effective indices for climate change, as they can contain a rich diversity of information about the composition of biotic precursor molecules and the environmental conditions. However, uncertainty exists while using n-alkane proxies owing to their physical, chemical, and biological effects. The microbial community is sensitive to environmental changes and can be useful for paleoclimatic studies owing to their diverse ecological roles. However, lipid biomarkers can only infer the biological origin of some specific groups and therefore, have limitations in studying the diversity of microbial community. With the development of modern molecular biological techniques, several recent studies have applied sedimentary DNA to reconstruct temporal changes in microbial ecology.
research objective: This study used the ancient DNA and n-alkanes preserved in the lacustrine-fluvial sediments from the Linxia Basin, and employed high throughput sequencing and geochemical analyses to understand the climatic conditions spanning the past 29 million years. The objective is to infer paleoenvironmental information and stepwise drying of this basin and understand how the microbial community evolution has responded to the climate change.
methods: Twenty sediment samples were collected from the bottom to the top of the Maogou section, from 28.5 to 4.4 Ma in a depth interval of 2 to 438 m. Two hundred and fifty grams of the samples were air-dried and ground to particles larger than 100 mesh, and then extracted continuously for 72 h with chloroform in a Soxhlet extractor. The total lipid extracts of the samples were directly analysed using GC–MS after drying at 20–25 °C. The Power Max DNA isolation kit (MO BIO Laboratories, Solana Beach, CA, USA) was used to extract DNA from 0.25 g mud samples using sterile tweezers and a spoon, following the manufacturer’s instructions. The sequencing was performed on an Illumina® Miseq platform, targeting the 16S rRNA gene variable region V3–V4 from the genomic DNA.
findings: The characteristics of n-alkanes indicate that the organic matter was derived from mixed sources (bacteria, algae, and higher plants), and a series of n-alkane proxies (ACL, n-C21−/n-C22+, Paq, and Pwax) established that the climate shifted to arid conditions at approximately 8 Ma. It is noteworthy that the relative abundance trends of two classes of microbes (Proteobacteria and Firmicutes) were negatively correlated. Furthermore, the increasing Firmicutes and the relatively decreasing Proteobacteria at approximately 8 Ma also corroborated this arid event. In addition, during this period, there was an extremely low abundance of archaea, which might correspond to severe climatic conditions around 8 Ma. Therefore, this study suggests that the microbial communities could serve as a potential tool for the reconstruction of paleoenvironments.

background: The Miocene–Pliocene boundary (MPB), which is defined formally at the base of the deep marine Mediterranean Trubi marls, occurred at ~5.3 Ma, five orbital precession cycles below the C3n.4n palaeomagnetic normal polarity chron. In the Mediterranean, the Messinian salinity crisis ended across the MPB. In a global context, the MPB marks a transition from a late Miocene cooling trend to the early-to-middle Pliocene Warm Period. It coincided with an atmospheric CO2 concentration rise of ~100–250 ppm, an increase with similar amplitude to the current rise due to anthropogenic emissions. The early-to-middle Pliocene Warm Period was the most recent period of persistently warmer-than-present conditions. During this warm interval, the Northern Hemisphere was largely ice-free and atmospheric CO2 concentrations were comparable to present-day levels. Detailed analysis of the MPB, therefore, enables investigation of the large-scale climate response to a natural atmospheric CO2 increase and global warming over equilibrium timescales for comparison with rapid out-of-equilibrium present-day responses. Today, Asia has wet monsoonal regions to the south and east of the Tibetan Plateau and arid continental regions to the north and west of the Tibetan Plateau. Both the Asian monsoon and the Westerlies are critical components of the global atmospheric circulation; they play a key role in the global climate system, impacting surface ocean circulation and driving air-sea heat, moisture, momentum fluxes, and carbon exchange. Our present understanding of Asian climate variability and dynamics relies primarily on Quaternary results, when a bipolar icehouse climate state was fully established and global climate was colder than today, with waxing and waning Northern Hemisphere ice sheets on orbital timescales.
research objective: Here we find that CO2-induced MPB warming both increased summer monsoon moisture transport over East Asia, and enhanced aridification over large parts of Central Asia by increasing evaporation, based on integration of our ~1–2-thousand-year (kyr) resolution summer monsoon records from the Chinese Loess Plateau aeolian red clay with existing terrestrial records, land-sea correlations, and climate model simulations. Here, we investigate Asian monsoon responses to the MPB global warming event and orbital forcing during the late Miocene–middle Pliocene in a global context by providing ~1–2-kyr resolution ~4.7-Myr-long proxy records (Al/Na, Rb/Sr, and lightness) spanning continuously from ~8.1 to ~3.4 Ma from the Shilou aeolian red clay succession on the eastern CLP. We integrate our high-resolution records with existing palaeoclimate records from the wider Asian region and land-sea correlations. We also present Earth System model simulation results with late Neogene boundary conditions, to assess the influence of CO2-induced MPB warming on spatial Asian hydroclimate changes.
challenges: Compared to relatively extensive Quaternary and modern climate studies, however, little is known about the detailed terrestrial climate changes related to this global warming event because high-resolution records that offer continuous coverage of distinct orbital variability from the late Miocene to the Pliocene are rare. At present, orbital climate variability is well constrained in Quaternary loess sequences, but is poorly resolved in the underlying red clay sequence because rapidly measurable magnetic susceptibility, which is used routinely to reveal orbital climate variability of Quaternary loess, does not capture distinct orbital signals in the red clay.
methods: First, following guidelines of the Pliocene Model Intercomparison Project phase 2 (PlioMIP2), we conducted a simulation with preindustrial boundary conditions, including modern orography, vegetation, ice sheets, lakes, and 280 ppm atmospheric CO2 concentration. The Pliocene simulation was initiated from the default preindustrial simulation (including deep ocean temperature) and was run for 2,050 model years. The late Miocene simulation was initiated from model year 1501 of the Pliocene experiment and was run for a further 550 model years. We, therefore, analysed the climatological means of the last 100 model years from each experiment.
dataset: All of our measured proxy data presented here are attached in the Supplementary Dataset 1 and are also available in the East Asian Paleoenvironmental Science Database (http://paleodata.ieecas.cn/index.aspx, Data https://doi.org/10.12262/IEECAS.EAPSD2021004). The model simulation data used to support our dynamic interpretations are available at: https://zenodo.org/record/4964420.
findings: Overall, the Shilou red clay lithological and proxy records suggest prominent orbital-scale monsoon variability throughout the late Miocene– middle Pliocene and a distinct transition to higher summer monsoon precipitation across the MPB.

background: Earth experienced sustained cooling since the Early Eocene Climate Optimum and shifted, at the Eocene-Oligocene transition [EOT; ~34 million years (Ma) before present (BP)], from a warm greenhouse state without permanent ice sheets on both poles to a cooler, but still substantially warmer than today, unipolar icehouse state with the sole continental-scale ice sheet on Antarctica. The Oligocene (23.03 to 33.9 Ma BP) is the first epoch in the newly established unipolar icehouse world. Average global deep ocean and sea surface temperature were ~3° and >8°C higher than today during the Oligocene, respectively. Oligocene proxy records suggest that atmospheric CO2 concentrations were between ~400 and ~800 parts per million (ppm) before ~24.5 Ma BP, embracing the present-day and projected values for the year 2100. The Asian monsoon is the largest monsoon system on Earth; it governs moisture supply over a vast area, extending from the low-latitude western Pacific and Indian Oceans to mid-latitude East Asia. Since its formation, climate to the south and east of the plateau has been strongly affected by the Asian monsoon.
research objective: Constraining monsoon variability and dynamics in the warm unipolar icehouse world of the Late Oligocene can provide important clues to future climate responses to global warming. Here, we use elemental and environmental magnetic records from this terrestrial sequence, which are related to regional hydroclimate fluctuations in the Lanzhou Basin, to provide insight to orbital variability and dynamics of monsoon precipitation on the NE Tibetan Plateau margin in the Late Oligocene high CO2 world.
methods: We measured hydroclimate proxies, i.e., rubidium-to-strontium ratio (Rb/Sr) and low-field magnetic susceptibility (χlf), at 10-cm stratigraphic intervals (corresponding to a ~4-ka time spacing) from the Late Oligocene red mudstones at the Duitinggou section. After removal of the weathered outcrop surface (at least the topmost 30 cm), we collected 937 samples at ~10-cm intervals for Rb/Sr and χlf measurements in the laboratory at the Institute of Earth Environment, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Xi’an, China. About 5 g of each sample was ground to <38 μm (passing a 200-mesh sieve) with an agate mortar and pestle. Powders were then used to determine Rb and Sr concentrations with an Innov-X Systems X-ray fluorescence spectrometer in soil mode using a tantalum X-ray tube operated at 50 kV in beam I, 40 kV in beam II, and 15 kV in beam III. The measurement time for each sample was at least 60 s. About 10 g of each sample was powdered and were then packed into nonmagnetic cubic boxes (2 cm × 2 cm × 2 cm) for low-field magnetic susceptibility (χlf) measurement with a Bartington Instruments MS2 magnetic susceptibility meter at 470 Hz.
dataset: Here, we present a ~4-thousand year (ka) resolution rubidium-to-strontium ratio and magnetic susceptibility records between 28.1 and 24.1 million years ago from a distal alluvial sedimentary sequence in the Lanzhou Basin (China) on the northeastern Tibetan Plateau margin.
findings: These Asian monsoon precipitation records exhibit prominent short (~110-ka) and long (405-ka) eccentricity cycles throughout the Late Oligocene, with a weak expression of obliquity (41-ka) and precession (19-ka and 23-ka) cycles. We conclude that a combination of eccentricity-modulated low-latitude summer insolation and glacial-interglacial Antarctic Ice Sheet fluctuations drove the eccentricity-paced precipitation variability on the northeastern Tibetan Plateau in the Late Oligocene high CO2 world by governing regional temperatures, water vapor loading in the western Pacific and Indian Oceans, and the Asian monsoon intensity and displacement.

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method used to analyze past climate conditions in the Qaidam Basin on the Tibetan Plateau?
Example.Answer: A data collection method used in the Qaidam Basin involves leaching lacustrine sediments with 1M HOAc to obtain Mn(II) concentrations, followed by geochemical analysis with ICP-OES and X-ray diffraction to study mineral compositions.

Example.Question: Could you provide an example of how high-resolution proxy records are used to explore late Miocene to Pliocene climate changes in Asia?
Example.Answer: High-resolution proxy records, such as Al/Na and Rb/Sr ratios, are used alongside climate model simulations to investigate Asian monsoon responses to the Miocene-Pliocene boundary global warming event, offering insights into orbital-scale climate variability.

Feature Specification.Question: What are the characteristics of data collection methods used to infer paleoenvironmental conditions in the Tibetan Plateau region?
Feature Specification.Answer: sediment records, geochemical analysis, X-ray diffraction, high throughput sequencing, concentration of elements and isotopes, proxies like n-alkanes and ancient DNA

Feature Specification.Question: What attributes are considered in datasets used to study monsoon variability and dynamics in the Tibetan Plateau region?
Feature Specification.Answer: rubidium-to-strontium ratios, low-field magnetic susceptibility, eccentricity, obliquity, precession

Definition.Question: What does 'elemental and environmental magnetic records' mean in the analysis of regional hydroclimate fluctuations?
Definition.Answer: Elemental and environmental magnetic records involve using the concentrations of specific elements and the magnetic properties of sediments to infer past environmental conditions. In regional hydroclimate studies, these records provide insights into past climate dynamics by reflecting changes in weathering, sediment sources, and depositional environments related to climate fluctuations.

Comparison.Question: How does the use of high-resolution proxy records in Shilou red clay compare to the elemental and environmental magnetic records in the Lanzhou Basin for studying Asian monsoon variability?
Comparison.Answer: High-resolution proxy records in Shilou red clay offer a detailed view of monsoon variability across the Miocene-Pliocene boundary with a focus on monsoon precipitation changes. In contrast, elemental and environmental magnetic records in the Lanzhou Basin provide insights into orbital variability and hydroclimate fluctuations during the Late Oligocene, emphasizing eccentricity-paced precipitation variability. Both methods explore monsoon dynamics but differ in their temporal focus and type of data used.

Interpretation.Question: What can the presence and relative abundance of different microbial communities in sediment cores tell us about past climatic events in the Linxia Basin?
Interpretation.Answer: The presence and relative abundance of different microbial communities, such as Proteobacteria and Firmicutes, in sediment cores can indicate shifts in environmental conditions. For example, an increase in Firmicutes and a decrease in Proteobacteria may correspond to arid events, providing a biological response to past climatic changes.

Interpretation.Question: In what ways does the integration of high-resolution proxy records and climate model simulations enhance our understanding of monsoon responses to historical global warming events?
Interpretation.Answer: Integrating high-resolution proxy records with climate model simulations allows for a comprehensive understanding of monsoon responses by correlating terrestrial and marine records with simulated climate dynamics. This approach helps in assessing the impact of CO2-induced warming and orbital forcing on regional hydroclimate changes, offering insights into the mechanisms driving monsoon variability.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the challenges in obtaining high-resolution continuous records of climate variability from basin sediment sequences in the Tibetan Plateau and its neighboring regions?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Intensive tectonic activity since the late Oligocene-Early Miocene in the northern Tibetan Plateau and the Central Asian orogenic belt yields coarser lithology with frequent changes in sediment facies in basin sequences, hindering a better understanding of the full range of aridification and its driving force using the basin sediment records.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is the use of lipid biomarkers in reconstructing paleoclimate from sedimentary records limited or uncertain?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Uncertainty exists when using n-alkane proxies owing to their physical, chemical, and biological effects, which can limit their effectiveness in studying the diversity of microbial communities and accurately inferring the biological origin of specific groups within paleoclimate studies.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes the difficulty in resolving orbital climate variability in the red clay sequences underlying the Quaternary loess in the Asian monsoon region?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Rapidly measurable magnetic susceptibility, commonly used to reveal orbital climate variability in Quaternary loess sequences, does not capture distinct orbital signals in the red clay, making it challenging to resolve detailed terrestrial climate changes related to global warming events in these sequences.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the primary objective of employing lipid biomarkers and ancient DNA in reconstructing paleoenvironmental conditions in the Linxia Basin over the past 29 million years?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The use of lipid biomarkers and ancient DNA aims to infer paleoenvironmental information and understand the stepwise drying of the Linxia Basin, as well as how the microbial community evolution has responded to climate change over millions of years.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the significance of investigating Asian monsoon responses to the Miocene–Pliocene boundary global warming event using proxy records and climate model simulations?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Investigating Asian monsoon responses helps to understand the spatial hydroclimate changes in Asia induced by the Miocene–Pliocene boundary warming event, providing a broader context of how CO2-induced warming affected regional climate dynamics and precipitation patterns.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What are the key techniques employed to measure and analyze mineral concentrations in sediment cores to reconstruct paleoclimate records?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Key techniques include leaching the sediments with 1M HOAc to obtain Mn(II) concentrations, followed by geochemical analysis using ICP-OES. X-ray diffraction (XRD) is used to identify major minerals, particularly carbonate minerals, in core samples.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How can ancient DNA and lipid biomarkers be utilized to infer paleoenvironmental conditions and climate change over geological time scales?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Ancient DNA and lipid biomarkers from lacustrine-fluvial sediments are used alongside high throughput sequencing and geochemical analyses to infer paleoenvironmental conditions. Microbial community changes and n-alkane proxies help reconstruct climate conditions and ecological responses over millions of years.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedural steps are involved in collecting and analyzing sediment samples to study monsoon variability during the Late Oligocene?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Sediment samples are collected at regular stratigraphic intervals and analyzed for hydroclimate proxies such as the rubidium-to-strontium ratio and magnetic susceptibility. Samples are ground, sieved, and measured using X-ray fluorescence spectrometry and magnetic susceptibility meters to assess regional hydroclimate fluctuations and monsoon dynamics.

Enablement.Question: What technological advancements have enabled the reconstruction of paleoclimate evolution in the Tibetan Plateau using sediment records?
Enablement.Answer: Technological advancements such as high throughput sequencing for microbial DNA analysis, inductively coupled plasma-optical emission spectrometry (ICP-OES) for geochemical analysis, and X-ray diffraction (XRD) for mineral analysis have enabled the reconstruction of paleoclimate evolution in the Tibetan Plateau using sediment records.

Enablement.Question: What conditions or methodologies enable the analysis of orbital-scale climate variability in ancient sedimentary sequences from the Tibetan Plateau?
Enablement.Answer: The analysis of orbital-scale climate variability in ancient sedimentary sequences is enabled by methodologies such as measuring hydroclimate proxies like rubidium-to-strontium ratio and low-field magnetic susceptibility, combined with high-resolution sampling intervals and integration with climate model simulations and proxy records.

Expectation.Question: Why might it be challenging to maintain continuous records of sedimentation in regions with intense tectonic activity?
Expectation.Answer: Intense tectonic activity can cause frequent changes in sediment facies and coarser lithology, which hinders the understanding of full ranges of aridification and its driving forces using basin sediment records.

Expectation.Question: Why is it important to integrate various proxy methods, such as lipid biomarkers and ancient DNA, in reconstructing paleoenvironments?
Expectation.Answer: Different proxies provide complementary information where lipid biomarkers offer insights into biotic composition and environmental conditions, while ancient DNA can reveal microbial community responses to climate changes, thus giving a fuller picture of past environments.

Expectation.Question: Why might eccentricity cycles have a more prominent impact on Asian monsoon precipitation records than obliquity or precession cycles during the Late Oligocene?
Expectation.Answer: The eccentricity-paced precipitation variability is likely driven by a combination of eccentricity-modulated low-latitude summer insolation and glacial-interglacial Antarctic Ice Sheet fluctuations, which affect regional temperatures and monsoon dynamics more significantly than obliquity or precession cycles.

Judgmental.Question: How would you assess the effectiveness of using ancient DNA and n-alkanes in reconstructing paleoenvironmental conditions over a multi-million-year timeline?
Judgmental.Answer: The effectiveness of using ancient DNA and n-alkanes in reconstructing paleoenvironmental conditions can be considered promising as they provide detailed insights into the climatic conditions over extended periods, such as the past 29 million years in the Linxia Basin. These proxies can reveal information about organic matter sources and microbial community changes, offering a complementary perspective to traditional geochemical analyses. However, challenges such as the uncertainty in using n-alkane proxies due to physical, chemical, and biological effects and the limitations in studying microbial community diversity solely through lipid biomarkers must be acknowledged.

Judgmental.Question: What do you think are the potential challenges researchers might face when utilizing magnetostratigraphy and orbital tuning techniques for dating deeper sediment cores?
Judgmental.Answer: Utilizing magnetostratigraphy and orbital tuning techniques for dating deeper sediment cores, such as in the SG-1b core from the Qaidam Basin, is generally reliable for establishing continuous timelines. However, challenges may include dealing with coarser lithology due to tectonic activity, which can cause frequent changes in sediment facies and impact dating precision. Furthermore, aligning magnetostratigraphy with orbital tuning requires high-resolution data and careful cross-validation with other dating methods to ensure accuracy.

Judgmental.Question: In your view, how could the integration of high-resolution proxy records with climate model simulations improve our understanding of historical climatic events in Asia?
Judgmental.Answer: Integrating high-resolution proxy records with climate model simulations can significantly enhance our understanding of historical climatic events, as demonstrated in studies investigating the Miocene-Pliocene boundary warming and Asian monsoon responses. Proxy records provide empirical data on past climate conditions, while simulations can offer insights into the dynamics and mechanisms driving these changes. This combined approach allows for a more comprehensive evaluation of climatic events, such as the impact of CO2-induced warming and orbital forcing, and helps in understanding the broader implications for global climate systems.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand how the integration of geochemical and geophysical data can enhance the understanding of tectonic-climate linkages.
Assertion.Answer: The integration of geochemical and geophysical data, such as the analysis of mineral compositions through X-ray diffraction and the determination of elemental concentrations using inductively coupled plasma-optical emission spectrometry, provides a comprehensive view of past environmental conditions. This combined approach allows researchers to link sediment records to tectonic activities and climate changes, such as those influenced by the uplift of the Tibetan Plateau and associated aridification. Geochemical data can reveal past climates, while geophysical measurements help understand the sediment deposition processes, enhancing the understanding of tectonic-climate linkages.

Assertion.Question: I can't make sense of how paleoclimate proxies are used to deduce orbital-scale climate variability.
Assertion.Answer: Paleoclimate proxies, such as rubidium-to-strontium ratios and magnetic susceptibility measurements, are used to infer past climate conditions and their responses to orbital forcing. These proxies are sensitive to changes in environmental conditions and can reflect variations in monsoon strength and precipitation patterns over time. By measuring these proxies in sedimentary sequences, researchers can identify cyclic patterns that correspond to known orbital cycles, such as eccentricity, obliquity, and precession, allowing for the reconstruction of climate variability on orbital timescales.

Request/Directive.Question: Please summarize the data collection techniques used to reconstruct paleoclimate conditions in the Tibetan Plateau and its surrounding regions.
Request/Directive.Answer: Data collection techniques used in the reconstructions include geochemical analysis of lacustrine sediments, high throughput sequencing for microbial DNA, X-ray diffraction for mineral identification, and the measurement of hydroclimate proxies such as rubidium-to-strontium ratio and magnetic susceptibility. These methods are applied to sediment samples collected from various sections and drill-core campaigns across the plateau and its neighboring areas.

Request/Directive.Question: Please outline potential datasets that could be used to study climate change impacts on the Tibetan Plateau from a paleoenvironmental perspective.
Request/Directive.Answer: Potential datasets include high-resolution proxy records from aeolian red clay, drill-core records with magnetostratigraphy for dating, sedimentary DNA sequences, and elemental and environmental magnetic records. These datasets provide insights into past climate conditions, monsoon variability, and hydroclimate fluctuations over various geological timescales.
